history.content:
I was a TA for CS 184, so I might be a tad biased, but:

It depends on what kind of game dev you're interested in. If you're planning on designing a custom 3D engine, then you'll definitely need to take 184 for its coverage of 3D-graphics oriented data structures, rendering techniques, approaches for animation, etc. Before taking 184, I myself have attempted to make a 3D engine from scratch, but self-teaching and online tutorials could not take me as far as I wanted. 184 showed me not just a lot of solid examples of good 3D graphics programming techniques, but I began to grasp more of the general understanding for how to engineer novel 3D rendering techniques or approaches.

Even if you plan on using an already-made established 3D game engine, 184 would still be helpful for understanding how to utilize them effectively. It's quite easy to find $10 meme games on steam that just aren't using their engine "right", and it shows in the horrible FPS drops or under-utilization of what the engine has to offer. If you want to just work in 2D dev, I would say that most consumer machines today are sufficiently fast to avoid those kinds of problems.

I can't say I can strongly recommend any particular CS class for game-dev-specific stuff, but in general game dev pulls from so many CS-in-practice concepts that an ordinary curriculum would probably prepare you for it. CS 188 (AI) might be particularly good because tons of games are simulation-oriented nowadays, and the more complex your game dynamics are, the more the algorithms designed to deal with "real-world" complexity become relevant. Perhaps someone can follow-up with more insight.

children.subject:
super useful class, and instructors/TAs are amazing.

It'll teach you the fundamentals of computer graphics, and the projects allow you to work on those fundamental concepts (rasterization, raytracing, mesh edit, etc.)

You could probably add CS160 as UI design is a big part of how the user interacts with the game. 61ab are obviously a must. 170 prob isn't directly applicable but I'd recommend everyone take that as you never know when you need an algorithm and chances are it's just a variation of something already made. If you're looking to design the actual game engine, you can start adding in more software engineering classes like the rest of the 160s (namely 168 and 162, the latter especially for console development) and 186. Those last ones you can get away without having for sure. It really depends what you wanna do within game development as the field takes bits of everything. But taking these classes will help ya have the tools for whatever you pick

Also a former TA for 184 so also biased, but I think the class has a lot to offer aside from what James discussed. The class has obvious benefits if you want to work on the graphics parts of game dev, but I think it also is hugely useful for giving you more experience with working on large, intricate projects. 

Anecdotally (not trying to flex sorry T_T) I'm currently interning at Nvidia working on games, and 184 is singlehandedly the most useful class and I'm actually using things I learned from 184 on pretty much a daily basis. 162 is actually a fairly close second though, so I would recommend that if you haven't! Especially if you might want to work on lower level game technologies. 184 and 162 have also, in my experience and from conversations with friends, been the most useful for interviewing at companies like Nvidia, Unity, Playstation, Pixar, etc. (Though I can't quite recall if those were for graphics positions or game dev positions). 

Basically what I've been learning is there is a _lot_ in the world of game dev, and tons of different positions requiring different exact skillsets. But 184 will always be useful to help you talk the language of graphics! 

Popping back up to a higher level, there's a game dev class I took from the Art department (I want to say Art 178?), that was run in Unity, so it's pretty practical in terms of letting you output a game at the end of the class. But we also went over a lot of game design methodologies, which I had never really been exposed to formally before, so that was pretty cool.
